subNodes.conversationText: root

Hail, strangers.  I am Gilathias.  I am most sorry to have brought you into this, and sorrier still that Voeae and I could not have parted on better terms.||***ga_journal-->String::Q_DRYAD    Int::10    Int::0    Int::0    Int::0    ***gc_is_in_combat-->NOT::True    String::$PC_SPEAKER    ***gc_local_int-->NOT::False    String::dryad_dead    String::1    String::gilathias1    ||
Tell me your tale, Quessir.|***gc_check_race_pc-->NOT::False String::2 |
Of course, my <brother/sister>.
I am originally of Evereska, but am a member of a small company of Evereskan elves who have an interest in protecting this vicinity.
[Continue.]
Though we travel and fight as a group, we are each of us rather given to solitude than to company, and spend many days apart, exploring the wood and scouting.
[Continue.]

One tenday this past summer I happened upon Voeae, or she upon me.  I had fallen asleep by this water; the grass here, now sere and scant, was full of flowers, and the drone of the bees was heavy in the air.
[Continue.]

A dryad will sometimes charm an elven or human beloved, but Voeae had no need of such magic--at first.  We spent many a day and night on this bank; it was a strange, bitter love--sometimes cruel, often fierce, never dull.
[Continue.]

But as the autumn approached, Voeae grew restless.  She spoke of the coming "dead-cold," and feared what would happen to me when it came.  She was never a reasonable creature, but she became worse.  I pleaded that I would have to leave her.
[Continue.]

She began to use her magic on me.  I let her; the best of our days in late summer passed in a kind of twilight, where I only half-knew what I was and what she was.  But suddenly I found that I had no will left at all.  She put me into a deep sleep, and wrapped her roots tight around me.
[Continue.]

In short, Voeae, whom I had loved, had made me a prison out of that love--a prison in which I would have died.  It pains me that we had to part like this, without the farewells of lovers--but such things happen.
Indeed they do, Gilathias.  But love is always a thing of beauty, tragic or not--though beauty can be a merciless thing.
Thank you for the tale, Gilathias.  Is there anything else I can do for you before you go?|***ga_global_int-->String::sympathetic    String::++    |
No, my friend.  It shall not be difficult for me to track down my company--our leader, Erebenian, must fear me dead, and I should return to him with all haste.  Thank you, and farewell!
|***ga_give_xp-->Int::200    Int::0    ***ga_global_int-->String::gilathias    String::1    ***ga_move_exit-->Int::4    Int::1    String::    String::gilathias1    |
Thank you for the tale, Gilathias--and you for the moralizing, Ianth.|***ga_global_int-->String::ironic String::++ |
[With disarming candor.] Well, , I am not a paladin for nothing. Is there anything more we can do for you, Gilathias?
[Nod.] Well, I suppose you should be on your way.
Is there anything more we can do for you?
We do not have much time.  Be brief.
What is your story?  Did the dryad enchant you?
Yes and no.  If it pleases you to hear my story, I will tell.
I am pleased to have freed you from the curse of that wicked creature.|***ga_global_int-->String::moral    String::++    |
Wicked?  I would not go that far.  But she was cruel, yes.  Hear my tale.
Indeed.  Explain yourself.|***ga_global_int-->String::abrasive    String::++    |
Not now!  We must do what we can about dryad--by Corellon, I am sorry it has come to this!|***gc_local_int-->NOT::True    String::dryad_dead    String::1    String::gilathias1    |
